Yeah -- a transaction is inherently stateful, so it's gotta be
managed as a=
 distinct resource space. Any GET on a resource
within the context of the t=
ransaction must identify the
transaction in the URI. Any GET on the origina=
l URI must be
treated as outside of any transaction.

Initiating a transact=
ion really creates a new view of the entire
resource space, so it makes sen=
se that any resources accessed
within the transaction would be accessed at =
URIs hierarchically
subordinate to the URI of the transaction itself. Howev=
er,
munging the existing URIs on the client is undesirable. Also, any
relat=
ive URIs inside the representations of those various
resources may be throw=
n off; the server would have to introspect
the representations it's returni=
ng and munge any URIs therein
itself, and the client would have to be disci=
plined about only
following URIs returned from the server (or built accordi=
ng to
rules returned from the server, as for an HTML form submission),
and =
emphatically not constructing URIs itself -- but then that's
just good REST=
 sense, anyway.

Justin
